Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Environmental and Extreme Multiphase Flows, Gainesville, FL, March 14 - 16, 2012

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1217409
PI: Balachandar

Volcanic eruptions, powder snow avalanches, turbidity currents, dust storms and bubble plumes are diverse examples of environmental flows. But they share a lot of common physics. Fundamentally all these flows are environmental examples of dispersed two-phase turbulence. For example, both in turbidity currents and powder snow avalanches the key common physics is in accurately capturing the competition between deposition and resuspension from the bottom boundary. Similarly, entrainment of ambient fluid is the process that plays a key role in the vertical development of volcanic and bubbly plumes. Despite these commonalities, the progress of mathematical models, closures and simulation techniques have gone on independently. Especially, the recent rapid expansion of research enterprise has greatly diminished the potential for cross fertilization of ideas. The purpose of the workshop is to bring world-class experts from these different disciplines and promote cross fertilization of ideas and methodologies. The workshop is held at the University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, from March 14th to March 16th of 2012.

The intellectual merit of the workshop is to identify key outstanding challenges that are common and thereby enable better understanding, modeling and predictive simulations of a broad class of complex environmental turbulent multiphase flow problems. The broader impact of the workshop will be through wide dissemination of the workshop results and findings through a dedicated website and also by publishing the key contributions as a state of the art book.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The "Workshop on Environmental and Extreme Multiphase Flows" was held at the University of Florida, Gainesville, USA. The dates of the workshop were from March 14 to March 16, 2012.

There were six oral sessions consisting of 28 keynote and invited presentations. On Thursday, March 15th there was also a poster session in theafternoon, with poster presentations by younger researchers, who are on their way to academic or industrial career. Most of the posters were from the NSF-PIRE supported students at the University of Florida. There were also posters from graduate student and postdoctoral visitors.

The wrokshop was attended by over 60 attendees with a good mix of senior researchers and young graduate students and postdocs. It was an international workshop with nine world-class participants from United Kingdom (1), Australia (1), France (2), Germany (1), Argentina (1), Canada (1), Srilanka (1) and Isreal (1), attending the workshop.

Theworkshop was attended by experts in dispersed multiphase turbulence in diverse environmental and geophysical flows. Volcanic eruptions, powder snow avalanches, turbidity currents, dust storms and bubble plumes are diverse examples that were represented at the meeting. The intellectual merit of the workshop was to identify key outstanding challenges that are common to all these flows and thereby enable better understanding, modeling and predictive simulations of a broad class of complex environmental turbulent multiphase flow problems. Some of the common underlying physics that we discussed at the workshop are multiscale turbulence, turbulenty settling, deposition and resuspension, entrainment, preferential accumulation, two-way coupling  and turbulence modulation. WE discussed how these mechanisms play a crucial role in the dynamics of the different environmental and extreme turbulent multiphase flows.
